Media: The New York Times
Review: It is pleasant to look at, easy to listen to and oddly recessive. It neither offends nor enthralls...'Am<U+00E9>lie' the musical seems to have no nationality, or sensibility, to call its own...All credit to this show<U+2019>s creative team, overseen by the director Pam MacKinnon, for giving coherent life to a tale that exists as much in Am<U+00E9>lie<U+2019>s imagination as in anywhere else...That the show<U+2019>s creators are aware of the potential dangers of cloying cuteness probably accounts for its seeming so subdued.

Media: Broadway News
Review: Soo almost single-handedly transforms this sugar-rich, gossamer adaptation of the popular French movie into an emotionally rewarding evening...The show does not condescend to the material, instead choosing to embrace its assorted oddities full-heartedly, even adding some of its own...MacKinnon<U+2019>s status as a relative newcomer to musicals reveals itself in the somewhat cramped staging...Fortunately, front and center for most of the musical<U+2019>s modest duration is the luminous Soo.

Media: Theatermania
Review: A tepid take on a much bolder film. Suffering from a derivative score, it features a main character who doesn't seem fully present in her own story...Director MacKinnon does capture the playful editing of the movie with her cinematic and inventive production..Not an unpleasant way to spend two hours; it's just not that memorable. Between its blandly whimsical score and inoffensively quirky love story, we cannot shake the feeling that we've seen this show before.

Media: BroadwayWorld
Review: <U+201C>MacKinnon enhances the quirks of the oddball text, set to Mess<U+00E9>'s indie-style music, with a delightful array of surprising, slightly surreal visuals applied with a strong hand that keep the whimsy from floating out of control. Which is fortunate, because 'Amelie' tends to meander about a bit when it comes to storytelling and song placement<U+2026>A low-key charmer. Phillipa Soo plays the young Parisian introvert with sly intelligence that welcomes you to her improvisational life.

Media: Time Out New York
Review: During this promising but never delivering musical fantasy, you can easily (and frequently) dream up ways the creative team might have better turned the 2001 film into a stage event that didn<U+2019>t cloy and harden into static quirk halfway through...Book writer Lucas and songwriters Mess<U+00E9> and Tysen are at pains to articulate a singable emotional center of the source while staying true to its careening, cinematic narrative. The two duties ultimately cancel each other out.

Media: Variety
Review: It<U+2019>s almost mandatory to have seen the movie if you hope to follow the erratic events of Craig Lucas<U+2019>s twee book...Soo's lovely voice isn<U+2019>t enough to animate the character...As listlessly played by Adam Chanler-Berat, Nino is a case study in vapidity...Messe<U+2019>s music is emphatically insipid, with zero flavor of Paris, and the songs keep landing in awkward moments...In the end, it<U+2019>s just wearying, looking for some logic in all this relentless whimsy.

Media: The Guardian (UK)
Review: Blandly enjoyable...There<U+2019>s nothing very much wrong with this musical. The book is affectionate; the songs are inarguably pleasant. But it<U+2019>s tricky to build a show around a protagonist whose main trait is wistful passivity...This is not to diminish the efforts of Soo and the director, Pam MacKinnon...'Am<U+00E9>lie' is the creme brulee of musicals <U+2013> a little sweet, a little mild, but difficult to push away all the same.

Media: Lighting & Sound America
Review: <U+201C>There's one indisputably great thing about <U+2018>Am<U+00E9>lie,<U+2019> and her name is Phillipa Soo<U+2026>A faux French frolic that consists of nothing but the frothiest conceits and allegedly adorable oddballs, all tethered to a plot so inconsequential that a meringue would weigh it down<U+2026>The songs often feel as skittish as Am<U+00E9>lie<U+2026>In its overreliance on a general mood of winsomeness, it can be something of a trial to sit through.<U+201D>

Media: New York Theater
Review: <U+201C>Am<U+00E9>lie<U+2019> features a fine cast; clever, playful design; and a pleasing if unmemorable pop score<U+2026>The colorful characters and fanciful subplots all felt part of the enchanting if ironic swirl on screen<U+2026>The stage at the Walter Kerr, by contrast, feels crowded with details, distractions and digressions that are sometimes hard to follow<U+2026>The musicalized vignettes are often presented like children<U+2019>s theater run amok. Media: Theater Life
Review: Director Pam MacKinnon proves she is as adept at staging enchanting adult fables as she is at enlivening dramas...The Gallic bon-bon features a sweet score by Daniel Messe and Nathan Tysen, a tidy book by Craig Lucas, and an enchanting lead performances by a spritely Phillipa Soo...A versatile ensemble delivering memorable work...At a fast 100 minutes, 'Am<U+00E9>lie' is a sweet and tasty creme br<U+00FB>l<U+00E9>e of a show.

Media: Talkin' Broadway
Review: Phillipa Soo is loaded with charm and knows how to use it to make the new musical 'Am<U+00E9>lie' something more than it could ever be on its own...But Soo's shimmering central presence only amplifies the troubles around her. Bookwriter Craig Lucas, composer-lyricist Daniel Mess<U+00E9>, lyricist Nathan Tysen, and director Pam MacKinnon may have been ultra faithful as far as the letter in escorting this quirky movie to the stage, but the underlying spirit is nowhere to be found.

Media: The Huffington Post
Review: <U+201C>Stars Soo and Chanler-Berat can sing very well but you wouldn<U+2019>t know it from the ungainly melodies they<U+2019>re asked to tackle<U+2026>The book is faithful to the movie in every detail except the one that matters: its spirit<U+2026>They seem to have made the wrong choice at every turn...Soo does not display the star power that this role desperately needs. That<U+2019>s not quite fair since no one could bring this story as written to life. Still, the charming Chanler-Berat does bring us in more.

Media: AM New York
Review: Soo, looking stunning, gives a winning, seemingly effortless performance, and there are nice supporting turns from Adam Chanler-Berat as Am<U+00E9>lie<U+2019>s sensitive crush and Tony Sheldon as her elderly neighbor...You appreciate their hard work, but it doesn<U+2019>t really come together...The soft pop score occasionally sounds pretty but is mostly unmemorable and derivative...The episodic structure leaves little in the way of advancing the plot. Media: The Hollywood Reporter
Review: This grating stage musical takes the slenderest of romances and drowns it in cartoonish quirks in place of genuine warmth or feeling...Moments that don't cry out to be musicalized get slathered in song, while others where music might have helped go unsung...With more swinging doors than most farces, this is a show that manages to be simultaneously frenetic and inert...The talented cast fights a losing battle to give these annoyingly artificial characters life.

Media: New York Magazine / Vulture
Review: Am<U+00E9>lie the character and thus 'Am<U+00E9>lie' the show remain alluringly, maddeningly remote...When a narrative is held together by tone instead of the working out of interpersonal conflict...there<U+2019>s no bright line between what<U+2019>s pertinent and what isn<U+2019>t...As a result, MacKinnon<U+2019>s staging, which has little choice but to underline the aesthetic, develops a bad case of nonspecific where-the-heck-is-this , often leaving the audience more amused than informed.

Media: New York Daily News

Media: Times Square Chronicles
Review: <U+201C>Vocally Soo is perfect<U+2026>The problem is her journey is so banal that we don<U+2019>t really care<U+2026>Chanler-Berat has wonderful chemistry with Soo<U+2026>The cast is all talented<U+2026>The direction by MacKinnon is well done for what the material allows...The biggest problem here is nothing really happens and what does is like a Hallmark card without the substance<U+2026>The music is monotonous<U+2026><U+2018>Am<U+00E9>lie<U+2019>  misses the complexity of a girl who has several layers to her.

Media: Deadline
Review: I had the luxury of seeing 'Am<U+00E9>lie' twice, and I admit to finding its charms more readily revealed on second viewing, The score, for one thing, is more sophisticated than a single hearing suggests, and perhaps more cunning...The authors, along with MacKinnon, avoid gratuitous winking, trusting both 'Am<U+00E9>lie' and Am<U+00E9>lie to work their charms. Media: Theater In The Now
Review: <U+201C>Fluffy and sweet. And that<U+2019>s about it...<U+2018>Amelie<U+2019> is a delectable world of whimsy and joy but the overall execution is mediocre at best. It never involves us, never really surprises.

Media: Musical Theater Review
Review: Whimsy is an elusive quality to capture in the Broadway vernacular of today...The result is an enterprise that is never cloying but never totally engaging. It certainly has its entertaining, even inspired moments, and you can admire the dedication and proficiency of the 13-person cast...Poignancy and grace<U+2014>as well as a little touch of French jauntiness in its score<U+2014>are elements that 'Am<U+00E9>lie' could use more of, along with its inherited whimsy.

Media: WNYC
Review: <U+201C>The production team has captured a surprising quirkiness that's often wonderful. But when the musical attempts to explore real feelings<U+2014>loneliness, isolation, fear<U+2014>the glow dims. It's not terrible. It's just meh. Part of the trouble is that Phillipa Soo, who plays Am<U+00E9>lie, often feels chilly and remote. Am<U+00E9>lie is trapped in her head, but instead of letting us in, Soo's sprite pushes us away<U+2026>The blurry ballads don't play to Soo's power pop vocal strength.

Media: Theater Pizzazz
Review: God knows Soo gives it her all, pert and chipper to a fault. And indeed, it is a fault. How much wide-eyed sweetness can we take ...While her character may be insipid, Soo<U+2019>s voice is anything but. Clear and soaring, it effortlessly fills the theater with Mess<U+00E9><U+2019>s songs, most of which are pleasantly diverting...It<U+2019>s hard to decipher director Pam MacKinnon<U+2019>s vision for the production...The overall effect is quirky, devoid of charm.

Media: StageZine
Review: What was once an enchanting, charming and colorful motion picture full of visual delights has been reduced to slow-motion comic strips devoid of whimsy or fairy-tale delights...The score is lifeless and dreary; no lilting French music or haunting melodies, just dirges. What should have been lighter-than-air direction is a plodfest of caricature thanks to Pam MacKinnon. Phillipa Soo gives her all to muster some life into the show, but the leaden material she is given drowns her.

Media: ZEALnyc
Review: <U+201C>I hate whimsy. I<U+2019>m also not particularly enamored of cute, quirky, oddball, eccentric, or twee. Unfortunately 'Am<U+00E9>lie' has all those things, in abundance<U+2026>Since everything is charming and, yes, whimsical, I can<U+2019>t really care much about any of it. No conflict, no fire. I<U+2019>m rooting for her and her potential love, but I don<U+2019>t really care all that much because everything is just so sweet. The stakes are barely visible<U+2026>The songs are nice. But nice, whether the songs or the story, just ain<U+2019>t enough.

Media: Village Voice
Review: <U+201C>Everybody works very hard and very thoroughly, everything seems to happen more or less in coherent sequence, but the end result seems all efficiency and no charm. This is especially unfortunate because 'Am<U+00E9>lie's' thread-thin story depends heavily on the kind of nonsensical, reality-defying charm we call pixilated...'Am<U+00E9>lie' lacks that lightness...A little relaxation of that insistent Broadway grip might have made it a great deal easier to enjoy.

Media: The Stage (UK)
Review: It's a tenderly drawn, small story, but it feels out of place amid the bombast and bigger effects that Broadway usually trades in. Pam MacKinnon's production is sweet and full of charm but it makes no lasting impression. The same is true of Daniel Messe and Nathan Tysen's score...It's not Phillipa Soo and Adam Chanler-Berat's fault that the material isn't in the same league as their earlier hit shows, and that charm only goes so far.

Media: The Wall Street Journal
Review: It is clear how little concern there is here for the wry Truffaut-esque wit of the 2001 film...The musical is so full of stage business that the main impression is of tumult, which is more evocative of Times Square than Paris...There are so many misjudgments of taste and style in the first two-thirds of the show that I was becoming immensely sympathetic to Am<U+00E9>lie<U+2019>s desire to avoid excessive human contact...Most songs were bland and mildly tuneful.

Media: Magical MissTari Tour
Review: <U+201C>Playwright/librettist Craig Lucas works his magic here. I was also quite taken with Nathan Tysen's smart and quirky lyrics<U+2026>If I wished the music had a little more French verve to it, OK. Not a deal breaker for me, but just a little bit would've been nice<U+2026>If your tolerance for quirk and whimsy is low, 'Amelie' might not be the show for you...Mainly, I just let myself go with the gentle charms of <U+2018>Amelie<U+2019><U+2026>Soo is simply delightful in the show<U+2026>It was sweet, wistful, and charming.

Media: The Telegraph (UK)
Review: Despite plenty of talent onstage and off, 'Am<U+00E9>lie, A New Musical' is a series of playful moments that don<U+2019>t add up to a memorable musical. What it does have going for it is a spirited cast of 13, including enchanting star Phillipa Soo...While the musical bounces along at such a clip, there<U+2019>s never time for tension to build...Heart is something this show abounds with, but the music suffers from Broadway-fied orchestrations and a certain sameyness.

Media: This Week in New York Blog
Review: Despite a promising cast and crew, the Broadway adaptation lacks all the exuberant and mysterious joi de vivre that made the film such a critical and popular success...The most touching parts of the film get lost in the over-staging and the lackluster book...What the production seems to miss is that Am<U+00E9>lie is not merely an adorable gamine doing cute things but a complex character living in a complicated, broken world that she is trying to fix; unfortunately, she can<U+2019>t fix the musical.

Media: Film Festival Traveler
Review: Soo is sweetly unassuming, with an affecting, natural singing voice, but the adaptation even one-ups the original at being annoyingly eccentric...The musical approximates the movie<U+2019>s oddball style, alongside stridently overwrought acting by the supporting cast. Director Mackinnon seems at a loss...and Mess<U+00E9><U+2019>s score<U+2014>with mediocre lyrics by Mess<U+00E9> and Tysen<U+2014>doesn<U+2019>t overcome Lucas<U+2019>s patchy book...'Am<U+00E9>lie' the musical is ultimately as shallow as its cinematic forebearer.

Media: Simon Parris Man in Chair
Review: As dainty and delectable as a well-cooked souffl<U+00E9>, the new stage musical 'Am<U+00E9>lie' is a feather-light confection of pure charm...In a perfect match of material and star, Phillipa Soo takes on the title role...Daniel Mess<U+00E9> and Nathan Tysen have crafted a gorgeous set of lilting melodies that are highly enjoyable at first listen...'Am<U+00E9>lie' is a lightweight affair, but its message of pursuing human connections remains a salient one.

Media: Two on the Aisle
Review: 'Am<U+00E9>lie' is<U+2014>there is no other way of putting it<U+2014>charming. Not in a cloying way, but with a sweet innocence...The problem with 'Am<U+00E9>lie' is that nothing really happens...There is no conflict, no problems, not even any deep-seated yearnings by Am<U+00E9>lie...Perhaps if the show featured outstanding music, or innovative music, or if dance had played a major role, the show might have been better...The cast is talented and achieves as much as possible from the material.

Media: Frequent Business Traveler
Review: Despite the presence of the talented Phillipa Soo in the title role, 'Am<U+00E9>lie' never seems to grab the audience to the point where they will care about the characters. You are a curmudgeon.=Also My wife and I saw this show in previews and thoroughly enjoyed it. We never saw the movie it was based on, but the story makes for a very good musical. The Walter Kerr is an intimate theater, with a balcony that hangs over much of the orchestra.The show itself is about a young girl named Amelie, who loses her mother to a tragic (but rather amusingly-presented) accident.
